questions.ocrQuestion:
The jacobian of \( p, q, r \) w.r.t \( x, y, z \) given \( p=x+y+z, q=y+z, r=z \) is
a) 0
b) 1
c) 2
d) -1
questions.onlyq_text: The jacobian of \( p, q, r \) w.r.t \( x, y, z \) given \( p=x+y+z, q=y+z, r=z \) is
questions.sol_html: Explanation: We have to find\[J=\frac{\partial(p, q, r)}{\partial(x, y, z)}=\left|\begin{array}{lll}\frac{\partial p}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial p}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial p}{\partial z} \\\frac{\partial q}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial q}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial q}{\partial z} \\\frac{\partial r}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial r}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial r}{\partial z}\end{array}\right|\]But \( p=x+y+z, q=y+z, r=z \) (taking partial derivative)\[\begin{array}{l}J=\left|\begin{array}{lll}1 & 1 & 1 \\0 & 1 & 1 \\0 & 0 & 1\end{array}\right|\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}=1, \frac{\partial p}{\partial y}=1, \frac{\partial p}{\partial z}=1, \frac{\partial q}{\partial x}=0, \frac{\partial q}{\partial y}=1, \frac{\partial q}{\partial z}=1, \frac{\partial r}{\partial x}=0,\right. \\\left.\frac{\partial r}{\partial y}=0, \frac{\partial r}{\partial z}=1\right)\end{array}\]On expanding we get\[J=1(1-0)=1\]Thus \( \mathrm{j}=1 \).
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
Given \( u=\frac{y z}{x}, v=\frac{z x}{y}, w=\frac{x y}{z} \) then the value of \( \frac{\partial(u, v, w)}{\partial(x, y, z)} \) is
a) 4
b) -4
c) 0
d) 1
questions.onlyq_text: Given \( u=\frac{y z}{x}, v=\frac{z x}{y}, w=\frac{x y}{z} \) then the value of \( \frac{\partial(u, v, w)}{\partial(x, y, z)} \) is
questions.sol_html: Explanation: By Data \( u=\frac{y z}{x}, v=\frac{z x}{y}, w=\frac{x y}{z} \)\[\begin{array}{l}J=\frac{\partial(u, v, w)}{\partial(x, y, z)}=\left|\begin{array}{lll}\frac{\partial u}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial u}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial u}{\partial z} \\\frac{\partial v}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial v}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial v}{\partial z} \\\frac{\partial w}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial w}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial w}{\partial z}\end{array}\right|=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\frac{-y z}{x^{2}} & \frac{z}{x} & \frac{y}{x} \\\frac{z}{y} & \frac{-z x}{y^{2}} & \frac{x}{y} \\\frac{y}{z} & \frac{x}{z} & \frac{-x y}{z^{2}}\end{array}\right| \\=\frac{-y z}{x^{2}}\left\{\left(\frac{-z x}{y^{2}}\right)\left(\frac{-x y}{y^{2}}\right)-\left(\frac{x}{z}\right)\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)\right\}-\left(\frac{z}{x}\right)\left\{\left(\frac{z}{y}\right)\left(\frac{-x y}{z^{2}}\right)-\left(\frac{y}{z}\right)\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)\right\} \\+\frac{y}{x}\left\{\left(\frac{z}{y}\right)\left(\frac{x}{z}\right)-\left(\frac{y}{z}\right)\left(\frac{-z x}{y^{2}}\right)\right\} \\=\frac{-y z}{x^{2}}\left\{\frac{x^{2}}{y z}-\frac{x^{2}}{y z}\right\}-\frac{z}{x}\left\{\frac{-x}{z}-\frac{x}{z}\right\}+\frac{y}{x}\left\{\frac{x}{y}+\frac{x}{y}\right\}=0+1+1+1=4\end{array}\]Therefore \( \frac{\partial(u, v, w)}{\partial(x, y, z)}=4 \).
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
If \( \mathrm{u}=\mathrm{x}+3 \mathrm{y}^{2}-\mathrm{z}^{3}, \mathrm{v}=4 \mathrm{x}^{2} \mathrm{yz}, \mathrm{w}=2 \mathrm{z}^{2}-\mathrm{xy} \) then \( \frac{\partial(u, v, w)}{\partial(x, y, z)} \) at \( (1,1,1) \).
a) -184
b) -90
c) 20
d) 40
questions.onlyq_text: If \( \mathrm{u}=\mathrm{x}+3 \mathrm{y}^{2}-\mathrm{z}^{3}, \mathrm{v}=4 \mathrm{x}^{2} \mathrm{yz}, \mathrm{w}=2 \mathrm{z}^{2}-\mathrm{xy} \) then \( \frac{\partial(u, v, w)}{\partial(x, y, z)} \) at \( (1,1,1) \).
questions.sol_html: Explanation: Given that \( u=x+3 y^{2}-z^{3}, v=4 x^{2} y z, w=2 z^{2}-x y \)\[\begin{array}{l}\frac{\partial(u, v, w)}{\partial(x, y, z)}=\left|\begin{array}{lll}\frac{\partial u}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial u}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial u}{\partial z} \\\frac{\partial v}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial v}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial v}{\partial z} \\\frac{\partial w}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial w}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial w}{\partial z}\end{array}\right|=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 6 y & -3 z^{2} \\8 x y z & 4 x^{2} z & 4 x^{2} y \\-y & -x & 4 z\end{array}\right| \\\frac{\partial(u, v, w)}{\partial(x, y, z)} \text { at }(1,1,1)=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 6 & -3 \\8 & 4 & 4 \\-1 & -1 & 4\end{array}\right| \\=1(16+4)-6(32+4)-3(-8+4)=-184 .\end{array}\]
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
If \( \mathrm{x}=\mathrm{r} \cos \theta, \mathrm{y}=\mathrm{r} \sin \theta \) then the value of \( \frac{\partial(x, y)}{\partial(r, \theta)} \) is
a) 1
b) 0
c) \( r \)
d) \( \frac{1}{r} \)
questions.onlyq_text: If \( \mathrm{x}=\mathrm{r} \cos \theta, \mathrm{y}=\mathrm{r} \sin \theta \) then the value of \( \frac{\partial(x, y)}{\partial(r, \theta)} \) is
questions.sol_html: Explanation: Wkt, \( \frac{\partial(x, y)}{\partial(r, \theta)}=\left|\begin{array}{ll}\frac{\partial x}{\partial r} & \frac{\partial x}{\partial \theta} \\ \frac{\partial y}{\partial r} & \frac{\partial y}{\partial \theta}\end{array}\right| \) but \( x=r \cos \theta, y=r \sin \theta \) Thus \( \left|\begin{array}{cc}\cos \theta & -r \sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & r \cos \theta\end{array}\right|=r \cos ^{2} \theta+r \sin ^{2} \theta=r \).
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
If \( \mathrm{u}+\mathrm{v}=\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{x}} \cos \mathrm{y} \) and \( \mathrm{u}-\mathrm{v}=\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{x}} \sin \mathrm{y} \) the value of \( J\left(\frac{u, v}{x, y}\right) \) is
a) \( e^{2 x} \)
b) \( \frac{e^{2} x}{2} \)
c) \( \frac{-e^{2} x}{2} \)
d) 0
questions.onlyq_text: If \( \mathrm{u}+\mathrm{v}=\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{x}} \cos \mathrm{y} \) and \( \mathrm{u}-\mathrm{v}=\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{x}} \sin \mathrm{y} \) the value of \( J\left(\frac{u, v}{x, y}\right) \) is
questions.sol_html: Explanation: wkt \( J\left(\frac{u, v}{x, y}\right)=\frac{\partial(u, v)}{\partial(x, y)}=\left|\begin{array}{ll}\frac{\partial u}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial u}{\partial y} \\ \frac{\partial v}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial v}{\partial y}\end{array}\right| \)But we have to find \( u \) and \( v \) first using given equation\[u+v=e^{x} \cos y \text {. }\]\[u-v=e^{x} \sin y \text {. }\]solving (1)\&(2)we get \( \mathrm{u}=\frac{e^{x}}{2} \) (cosy+siny)\[\begin{array}{l}\mathrm{v}=\frac{e^{x}}{2}(\cos y-\sin y) \\\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}=\frac{e^{x}}{2}(\cos y+\sin y) \\\frac{\partial v}{\partial x}=\frac{e^{x}}{2}(\cos y-\sin y) \\\frac{\partial u}{\partial y}=\frac{e^{x}}{2}(\cos y-\sin y) \\\frac{\partial v}{\partial y}=\frac{e^{x}}{2}(-\cos y-\sin y)\end{array}\]\[J\left(\frac{u, v}{x, y}\right)=\left|\begin{array}{cc}\frac{e^{x}}{2}(\cos y+\sin y) & \frac{e^{x}}{2}(\cos y-\sin y) \\\frac{e^{x}}{2}(\cos y-\sin y) & \frac{e^{x}}{2}(-\cos y-\sin y)\end{array}\right|\]\( \left(\frac{e^{x}}{2}\right)\left(\frac{e^{x}}{2}\right)\left\{-(\text { cosy }+\sin y)^{2}-(\text { cosy-siny })^{2}\right\} \ldots . . .\left(\right. \) expanding \& solving by taking \( \left.\cos ^{2} y+\sin ^{2} y=1\right) \) \( =\frac{-e^{2} x}{2} \)
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
Which among the following is the definition of Jacobian of \( u \) and \( v \) w.r.t \( x \) and \( y \) ?
a) \( J\left(\frac{x, y}{u, v}\right) \)
b) \( J\left(\frac{u, v}{x, y}\right) \)
c) \( \frac{\partial(x, y)}{\partial(u, v)} \)
d) \( \frac{\partial(u, x)}{\partial(v, y)} \)
questions.onlyq_text: Which among the following is the definition of Jacobian of \( u \) and \( v \) w.r.t \( x \) and \( y \) ?
questions.sol_html: Explanation: \( J\left(\frac{u, v}{x, y}\right)=\frac{\partial(u, v)}{\partial(x, y)}=\left|\begin{array}{ll}\frac{\partial u}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial u}{\partial y} \\ \frac{\partial v}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial v}{\partial y}\end{array}\right| \)
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
Compute the Jacobian, \( \frac{\partial(x, y)}{\partial(u, v)} \), of the coordinate transformation \( x=u^{2}-v^{4} \), \( y=u v \).
(a) \( 2 u^{2}+4 v^{4} \)
(b) \( x u-y v \)
(c) \( 3 u^{2}+7 v^{6} \)
(d) \( 2 u^{2} \)
questions.onlyq_text: Compute the Jacobian, \( \frac{\partial(x, y)}{\partial(u, v)} \), of the coordinate transformation \( x=u^{2}-v^{4} \), \( y=u v \).
questions.sol_html: Solution. \( \left|\begin{array}{rr}2 u & -4 v^{3} \\ v & u\end{array}\right|=2 u^{2}+4 v^{4} \).
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
If \( u \) and \( v \) are continuous and differentiable functions of two independent variables \( x \) and \( y \), then Jacobian of \( u, v \) with respect to \( \mathrm{x}, \mathrm{y} \) is
A. \( \frac{\partial(u, v)}{\partial(x, y)} \)
B. \( \frac{\partial(u, y)}{\partial(x, y)} \)
C. \( \frac{\partial(x, v)}{\partial(x, y)} \)
D. \( \frac{\partial(x, y)}{\partial(u, v)} \)
questions.onlyq_text: If \( u \) and \( v \) are continuous and differentiable functions of two independent variables \( x \) and \( y \), then Jacobian of \( u, v \) with respect to \( \mathrm{x}, \mathrm{y} \) is
questions.sol_html: Solution. \( \left|\begin{array}{rr}2 u & -4 v^{3} \\ v & u\end{array}\right|=2 u^{2}+4 v^{4} \).
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
If \( u v, w \) are continuous and differentiable functions of three independent variables \( x, y, z \) then Jacobian of \( u, v, w \) with respect to \( \mathrm{x} \), \( y, z \) is
E. \( \frac{\partial(u, v, w)}{\partial(x, y, z)} \)
F. \( \frac{\partial(u, y, w)}{\partial(x, y, z)} \)
G. \( \frac{\partial(x, v, z)}{\partial(x, y, w)} \)
H. \( \frac{\partial(x, y, z)}{\partial(u, v, w)} \)
questions.onlyq_text: If \( u v, w \) are continuous and differentiable functions of three independent variables \( x, y, z \) then Jacobian of \( u, v, w \) with respect to \( \mathrm{x} \), \( y, z \) is
questions.sol_html: Solution. \( \left|\begin{array}{rr}2 u & -4 v^{3} \\ v & u\end{array}\right|=2 u^{2}+4 v^{4} \).
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
Let \( u \) and \( v \) are functions of two independent variables \( x \) and \( y \). If Jacobian of \( u, v \) with respect to \( \mathrm{x}, \mathrm{y} \) is \( \mathrm{J} \), then \( \mathrm{J} \) ' is
A. \( \frac{\partial(u, v)}{\partial(x, y)} \)
B. \( \frac{\partial(u, y)}{\partial(x, y)} \)
C. \( \frac{\partial(x, v)}{\partial(x, y)} \)
D. \( \frac{\partial(x, y)}{\partial(u, v)} \)
questions.onlyq_text: Let \( u \) and \( v \) are functions of two independent variables \( x \) and \( y \). If Jacobian of \( u, v \) with respect to \( \mathrm{x}, \mathrm{y} \) is \( \mathrm{J} \), then \( \mathrm{J} \) ' is
questions.sol_html: Solution. \( \left|\begin{array}{rr}2 u & -4 v^{3} \\ v & u\end{array}\right|=2 u^{2}+4 v^{4} \).

A. 2
B. -1
C. 1
D. \( \frac{1}{2} \)
questions.onlyq_text: If \( x=r \cos \theta \) and \( y=r \sin \theta \), then JJ' is equal to
questions.sol_html: Solution. \( \left|\begin{array}{rr}2 u & -4 v^{3} \\ v & u\end{array}\right|=2 u^{2}+4 v^{4} \).

questions.ocrQuestion:
If \( u=f_{1}(x, y), v=f_{2}(x, y) \) and \( x=\Phi_{1}(r, \theta), y=\Phi_{1}(r, \theta) \) then \( \frac{\partial(u, v)}{\partial(r, \theta)} \)
is equal to
A. \( \frac{\partial(u, v)}{\partial(x, y)} \cdot \frac{\partial(u, y)}{\partial(x, y)} \)
B. \( \frac{\partial(u, v)}{\partial(x, y)} \cdot \frac{\partial(r, \theta)}{\partial(x, y)} \)
C. \( \frac{\partial(u, v)}{\partial(r, \theta)} \cdot \frac{\partial(r, \theta)}{\partial(x, y)} \)
D. \( \frac{\partial(u, v)}{\partial(x, y)} \cdot \frac{\partial(x, y)}{\partial(r, \theta)} \)
questions.onlyq_text: If \( u=f_{1}(x, y), v=f_{2}(x, y) \) and \( x=\Phi_{1}(r, \theta), y=\Phi_{1}(r, \theta) \) then \( \frac{\partial(u, v)}{\partial(r, \theta)} \)is equal to
questions.sol_html: Solution. \( \left|\begin{array}{rr}2 u & -4 v^{3} \\ v & u\end{array}\right|=2 u^{2}+4 v^{4} \).

questions.ocrQuestion:
If \( f_{1}(x, y, u, v)=0 \) and \( f_{2}(x, y, u, v)=0 \) are two implicit functions then \( \frac{\partial(x, y)}{\partial(u, v)}= \)
a) \( (-1)^{2}\left(\frac{\frac{\partial\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right)}{\partial(u, v)}}{\frac{\partial\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right)}{\partial(x, y)}}\right) \)

d) \( (-1)^{2}\left(\frac{\frac{\partial\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right)}{\partial(x, y)}}{\frac{\partial\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right)}{\partial(x, y)}}\right) \)

b) \( -\left(\frac{\frac{\partial\left(f_{1}, f_{2}, f_{3}\right)}{\partial\left(w_{1}, z\right)}}{\frac{\partial\left(f_{1}, f_{2}, f_{3}\right)}{\partial(u, v, w)}}\right) \)
c) - \( \left(\frac{\frac{\partial\left(f_{1}, f_{2}, f_{3}\right)}{\partial(x, v, w)}}{\frac{\partial\left(f_{1}, f_{2}, f_{3}\right)}{\partial(u, v, w)}}\right) \)
d) \( -\left(\frac{\frac{\partial\left(f_{1}, f_{2}, f_{3}\right)}{\partial(x, y, z)}}{\frac{\partial\left(f_{1}, f_{2}, f_{3}\right)}{\partial(u, v, w)}}\right) \)

c) - \( \left(\frac{\frac{\partial\left(f_{1}, f_{2}, f_{3}\right)}{\partial(x, v, w)}}{\frac{\partial\left(f_{1}, f_{2}, f_{3}\right)}{\partial(u, v, w)}}\right) \)
d) \( -\left(\frac{\frac{\partial\left(f_{1}, f_{2}, f_{3}\right)}{\partial(x, y, z)}}{\frac{\partial\left(f_{1}, f_{2}, f_{3}\right)}{\partial(u, v, w)}}\right) \)
